items.title: TechCrunch All Stage 2025 Welcomes Boldstart Partner Ellen Chisa
items.summary:
- Ellen Chisa, partner at Boldstart Ventures and experienced founder, will discuss *early-stage enterprise investing* at TechCrunch All Stage 2025 in Boston.  
- She brings *deep product and technical expertise* from her background including co-founding Darklang and roles at Kickstarter and Lola Travel.  
- Attendees can expect *practical startup advice* on securing investor conviction, avoiding pitfalls, and building scalable enterprise software.

items.title: SpaceX’s Starbase Silences on Recent Crane Collapse Incident
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- A crane collapsed on June 23 at SpaceX's South Texas launch complex within the new city of *Starbase*, but officials have not disclosed if there were any injuries.  
- Despite Starbase's recent transparency regarding rocket explosions, city officials, mostly SpaceX employees, have remained silent on the crane incident amid ongoing community restrictions and a $1.5 million loan from SpaceX.  
- OSHA has opened an investigation into the collapse, though SpaceX's history of limited cooperation with safety inspectors raises concerns about transparency and accountability at the facility.

items.title: Startups Weekly: Tech and the law
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- This week in startups featured major acquisitions like Rubrik buying Predibase to enhance AI agent adoption, and Kadmos acquired by NYK Line to expand fintech services. Legal battles continue with Getty Images dropping a lawsuit against Stability AI amid ongoing challenges.  
- Funding highlights include Harvey AI's rapid $300M Series E at a $5B valuation, Abridge's growth doubling valuation to $5.3B, and significant rounds for Kalshi, Finom, and Indian drone startup Raphe mPhibr.  
- Other notable startups raised capital for sustainable and AI-driven tech, including Novoloop's $21M for plastic upcycling and Lux Aeterna's $4M pre-seed aiming for reusable satellites by 2027.

items.title: PetLibro Launches AI-Powered Scout Smart Camera for Pets
items.summary:
- PetLibro's new Scout Smart Camera features **AI-powered pet recognition**, real-time monitoring, two-way audio, and tracks multiple pet activities including eating and litter box use.  
- Unique to Scout is its ability to identify individual pets with a dynamic recognition system and provide **cute, descriptive insights** about pet behavior, enhancing owner engagement.  
- Priced at $100, the camera requires a subscription for AI features, with upcoming enhancements like bark and meow detection planned to compete with other products like Furbo's AI camera.

items.title: TechCrunch All Stage 2025: Jason Kraus on Turning Chaos into Momentum
items.summary: - *TechCrunch All Stage 2025* on July 15 in Boston offers founders actionable insights on fundraising, hiring, and scaling from experienced leaders. - Jason Kraus, founder of *Prepare 4 VC*, will share a tactical playbook for overcoming early-stage startup chaos and gaining investor readiness. - Limited-time discounted tickets are available, including a Founder Pass for $155 and student tickets for $99.

items.title: Meta Buys Over 1 GW of Renewables to Power Its Data Centers
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Meta has significantly expanded its renewable energy portfolio by securing over **1 gigawatt** of solar and wind power across Ohio, Arkansas, and Texas.
- New projects will come online by **2027-2028**, including collaborations with Invenergy, Adapture Renewables, AES, and a geothermal plant with XGS Energy.
- This move boosts renewable energy use amid political challenges targeting subsidies, with solar power enabling quicker deployment for data centers.

items.title: SCOTUS Upholds Texas Age Verification Law for Porn Sites
items.summary: - The U.S. Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that Texas can require websites with sexual content to verify visitors' ages via government IDs or third-party platforms. - This decision impacts internet privacy concerns amid widespread data breach risks and LGBTQ rights fears about censorship of non-pornographic content. - Eighteen states already have such laws, signaling a potential nationwide push for stricter online age verification.

items.title: Denmark clamps down on deepfakes by letting people copyright their own features
items.summary:
- Denmark plans to amend copyright law to give citizens rights over their *body, facial features,* and *voice* to combat deepfakes.
- The law aims to protect individuals against misuse of generative AI imagery and audio.
- This effort has cross-party political support and contrasts with U.S. state-level deepfake laws currently facing federal challenges.

items.title: David H. Rosmarin’s Founder-Focused Approach to Anxiety at TechCrunch All Stage
items.summary:
- Dr. David H. Rosmarin, a clinical psychologist and Harvard Medical School professor, will lead a roundtable at TechCrunch All Stage 2025 focused on *turning anxiety into a strategic advantage* for startup founders.
- The session highlights practical tools to *channel pressure into better decision-making*, build *emotional resilience*, and lead authentically amid uncertainty.
- Rosmarin emphasizes that anxiety, often seen as a liability, can be one of the most *underutilized tools* in startup leadership.

items.title: Rollback Rates: TechCrunch All Stage Early Launch Prices Return
items.summary:
- TechCrunch All Stage founder summit in Boston returns July 15, with **early launch ticket prices rolled back**: $155 for founders, $250 for investors.
- Event features **actionable sessions on funding, scaling, AI**, live pitch competitions, curated networking, and an expo hall for startups.
- Speakers include top VCs and founders like **Jahanvi Sardana, Ellen Chisa, Tiffany Luck**, offering strategies for growth, funding, and AI impact.

items.title: German Official Urges Apple, Google to Remove DeepSeek Over Data Privacy
items.summary:
- A German data protection official has reported the Chinese AI app *DeepSeek* to Apple and Google for illegally transferring users' data to China.
- The app allegedly fails to provide *sufficient evidence* of data protection as required by *EU laws*.
- Previously, Italy banned DeepSeek for similar reasons; the app's data is collected and stored in China, raising privacy concerns.

items.title: OpenAI hires team behind AI recommendation startup Crossing Minds
items.summary: - **Crossing Minds**, an AI recommendation startup focused on e-commerce personalization, is joining **OpenAI**. - The startup, backed by major investors, has raised over $13.5M and worked with brands like Intuit and Chanel. - This move strengthens OpenAI's positioning in AI-driven shopping experiences and personalization technologies.

items.title: Meta in talks to acquire voice cloning startup Play AI
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary: - *Meta* is in discussions to acquire Play AI, a voice cloning startup, to enhance its consumer-facing AI features. - Play AI specializes in cloning various voices for AI use cases like customer service and has raised $23.5M from notable investors. - The acquisition would allow Meta to integrate *audio capabilities* into its creative AI suite, complementing existing chatbot and video editing features.

items.title: Redwood Materials Launches Energy Storage Business Targeting AI Data Centers
items.summary: - **Redwood Materials** has launched **Redwood Energy**, a new energy storage business utilizing retired EV batteries to power AI data centers, starting with a 12 MW solar-powered microgrid for Crusoe's AI infrastructure. - The company recycles over 70% of North America's used EV batteries and plans to deploy **20 GWh of grid-scale storage by 2028**, positioning it as a leading repurposer of used EV battery packs. - This initiative represents a profitable, scalable solution addressing energy storage challenges, repurposing batteries economically while supporting sustainability and the growing AI data center market.

items.title: AI Startup Studio Audos Aims to Launch 100,000 Companies Annually
items.summary: - Audos, a New York startup studio, uses **AI tools** to help *everyday entrepreneurs* build million-dollar businesses without technical skills. - Instead of taking equity, Audos charges a **15% revenue share** in exchange for funding, AI business tools, and social media marketing. - The startup aims to democratize entrepreneurship by launching hundreds of thousands of smaller, sustainable companies, called 'donkeycorns,' rather than chasing unicorns.

items.title: Jahanvi Sardana on How Top Startups Reshape Markets at TechCrunch All Stage
items.summary:
- **TechCrunch All Stage** summit in Boston gathers 1,200 founders and VCs to discuss scaling startups and market innovation.
- Jahanvi Sardana, partner at Index Ventures, will lead a breakout session on creating and expanding Total Addressable Market (TAM) using case studies from companies like Datadog and Airbnb.
- This session offers founders *practical strategies* for scaling and insights into how leading startups influence their industries' future.

items.title: Google launches Doppl, an AI app for virtual outfit try-ons
items.summary:
- Google introduced *Doppl*, an experimental AI app that lets users virtually try on clothes by uploading their photo and overlaying outfit images from any source.
- The app can generate both *images and AI videos* of users wearing selected outfits, enhancing the virtual try-on experience.
- Currently available in the U.S. on iOS and Android, Doppl aims to make style exploration fun and assist Google’s future AI fashion efforts.

items.title: Why a16z VC believes Cluely is the new blueprint for AI startups
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Cluely, a startup known for its controversial 'cheat on everything' product and rage-bait marketing, raised $15 million from Andreessen Horowitz, sparking debate.
- a16z partner Bryan Kim emphasizes that in the AI era, *speed and momentum* in marketing and product development are crucial for success, not just building perfect products.
- Cluely's viral, polarizing marketing approach exemplifies this theory, aiming to build its product quickly while capturing significant consumer attention.

items.title: TechCrunch All Stage: Using AI to Supercharge MVPs with Chris Gardner
items.summary:
- *Chris Gardner*, investing partner at Underscore VC, leads a breakout session on *leveraging AI* to build *minimum viable products* (MVPs) effectively at TechCrunch All Stage on July 15 in Boston.
- The session emphasizes balancing the speed of AI-driven development with preserving the *human element* crucial to product success.
- Limited-time *60% discounts* on Investor and Founder Passes are available for access to this and many other expert startup sessions.

items.title: Apple updates EU App Store rules with complex new fees
items.summary:
- Apple updated its developer policies to comply with the EU Digital Markets Act, introducing a more complex fee structure instead of dropping the Core Technology Fee (CTF).
- New fees include an acquisition fee (2%) plus a Store Services fee (5% or 13%), with tiered service options for developers and a Core Technology Commission (CTC) replacing the CTF by 2026.
- EU developers can now link to alternative payment methods without restrictions on communication channels, though critics like Epic Games call Apple's compliance "malicious" and anti-competitive.

items.title: Travis Kalanick aims to buy Pony.ai with Uber's potential help
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- *Travis Kalanick*, Uber founder, seeks to acquire the U.S. arm of *Pony.ai*, a Chinese autonomous vehicle company.
- The deal may involve Uber, marking Kalanick's return to self-driving technology after his 2017 exit.
- Pony.ai went public recently with a $4.5 billion valuation; Kalanick will continue running CloudKitchens if acquisition succeeds.

items.title: Windows Kills the Blue Screen of Death
items.summary:
- The iconic *Blue Screen of Death* (BSOD) is being replaced by the *Black Screen of Death* as part of Windows' *Resiliency Initiative*.
- This update follows the massive *CrowdStrike outage* in 2024 that impacted millions, prompting Microsoft to embed deeper security and recovery features.
- The change symbolizes nearly 40 years of tech history, aiming to make system failures less disruptive with a simplified interface.

items.title: CoreWeave CEO Michael Intrator Becomes Deca-Billionaire in 3 Months
items.summary: - *Michael Intrator's net worth* soared to about **$10 billion** within three months after CoreWeave's 2025 IPO, the biggest tech IPO so far this year raising $1.5 billion. - CoreWeave provides *AI cloud services* powered by Nvidia GPUs, serving customers like *Microsoft* and *OpenAI,* with OpenAI having a $12 billion deal. - Despite $8.8 billion in debt and $315 million net loss in Q1, *investors remain bullish*, boosting stock nearly 300%, reflecting AI sector enthusiasm and Intrator’s journey from crypto-mining origins to billionaire status.

items.title: Threads Adds Independent Hidden Words Filtering and Time Limits
items.summary:
- *Threads* now lets users manage **Hidden Words filters independently** from Instagram, personalizing content separately on each platform.
- Users can set **time limits up to 30 days** for filters, allowing temporary blocking to avoid spoilers or unwanted content.
- These updates signal Meta's push to make Threads a more standalone social network, with ongoing feature expansions.

items.title: Google Photos merges classic search with AI to speed up results
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary: - Google Photos has improved its AI-powered 'Ask Photos' search feature to deliver faster and more reliable results by combining classic search for simple queries with AI for complex ones. - The feature, paused earlier due to latency and quality issues, now resumes rollout in the U.S. with enhanced speed and accuracy. - Users must be 18+, use English, and enable Face Groups to access Ask Photos, which integrates natural language search and metadata analysis.

items.title: Uber Dominates Atlanta's Autonomous Ride-Hailing & Delivery
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary: - Uber Eats launches *sidewalk delivery robots* in Atlanta through Serve Robotics, shortly after debuting a commercial robotaxi service with Waymo. - Serve Robotics, spun out of Uber in 2021, expands autonomous deliveries beyond campuses to urban environments, scaling from 100 bots in LA to an expected 2,000 nationwide by end of 2025. - Delivery robots operate 9 a.m. to 10 p.m. serving areas like Midtown and Downtown Atlanta with popular restaurants including Shake Shack.

items.title: Rivian cuts dozens on manufacturing team ahead of R2 launch
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary: - Rivian has laid off around **140 employees** (~1% of workforce), mainly in manufacturing, to improve **operational efficiency** ahead of the **R2 SUV launch in 2026**. - Cuts target roles causing “process inefficiencies,” with affected staff encouraged to apply for other company positions. - This follows multiple workforce reductions since early 2024 amid ongoing EV market pressures.

items.title: Elon Musk Fires Tesla's Top Sales Executive Amid Sales Decline
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary: - Elon Musk has reportedly fired Omead Afshar, Tesla’s VP of sales and manufacturing in North America and Europe. - Afshar's departure coincides with Tesla’s first annual sales drop since mass EV production began and a 71% profit decline. - Afshar had a controversial past involving an internal probe and investigations related to purchases for a glass building Musk desired.

items.title: US, French Authorities Arrest Hackers Behind BreachForums
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary: - *Five hackers* linked to the notorious cybercrime forum **BreachForums** have been arrested by US and French authorities. - British national **Kai West (IntelBroker)**, accused of causing over **$25 million in damages** via a years-long hacking scheme, was arrested in France and faces extradition. - The arrests raise hopes for the *permanent closure* of BreachForums, which was seized twice in 2023 and 2024.

items.title: Homeland Security warns of Iran-backed cyberattacks targeting US networks
items.summary: - The U.S. Homeland Security issued a bulletin warning of *Iran-backed cyberattacks* on U.S. networks amid escalating tensions with Israel and Iran. - Both *government-linked hackers* and hacktivists are expected to target poorly secured U.S. systems to disrupt operations. - These warnings follow recent U.S. and Israeli air strikes on Iran’s nuclear sites and corresponding cyberattacks by pro-Israel groups.

items.title: Meta Hires Leading OpenAI Researcher for AI Reasoning Models
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- *Meta* has hired Trapit Bansal, a key OpenAI researcher who helped develop their first AI reasoning model, to boost its *AI superintelligence lab*.
- Bansal's move underscores Meta's aggressive strategy, including $100 million packages, to lead in *AI reasoning capabilities*.
- This hire may enhance Meta's AI offerings beyond its existing Llama family, signaling intensified competition in *advanced AI research*.

items.title: Google launches Offerwall to help publishers amid AI-induced traffic loss
items.summary:
- Google introduced **Offerwall**, a new tool in Google Ad Manager enabling publishers to monetize content beyond traditional ads using **micro payments, surveys, ads, and more**.
- The tool employs AI to optimize when it appears to visitors and allows customization; early testing showed a **5-15% revenue lift** for publishers.
- Offerwall integrates third-party services like **Supertab** for flexible paid access, aiming to counteract the decline in search traffic caused by AI features.

items.title: Suno Acquires WavTool Amid Legal Battles with Music Labels
items.summary:
- *Suno*, an AI music company facing lawsuits from major music labels, acquired *WavTool*, a browser-based AI digital audio workstation, to boost its song editing capabilities.
- WavTool offers features like *stem separation* and *AI music assistance*, which Suno plans to integrate into its new editing interface.
- The acquisition follows recent legal challenges about alleged copyright infringement but coincides with Suno’s $125 million funding round, signaling growth ambitions.

items.title: Jeff Bezos Courts Trump Following Musk Spat
items.summary: - Jeff Bezos is leveraging the recent *public spat* between Donald Trump and Elon Musk to strengthen ties with Trump and boost *Blue Origin*'s government contracts. - Bezos spoke twice with Trump, with Blue Origin's CEO meeting Trump’s chief of staff; Trump expressed interest in a *crewed Moon mission* during his term. - This move follows Musk's feud with Trump, including threats over Musk’s government subsidies and NASA leadership conflicts, highlighting a strategic pivot toward lunar missions.

items.title: People use AI for companionship much less than we’re led to believe
items.author: Ram Iyer
items.summary:
- A report by Anthropic reveals only *2.9%* of interactions with the AI chatbot Claude involve emotional support or personal advice, with *companionship and roleplay under 0.5%*.  
- Most users engage Claude for *work and productivity*, especially content creation, though some turn to it for coaching and mental health advice.  
- Chatbots remain imperfect, prone to *hallucinations, wrong information,* and potential *safety risks*, highlighting the current limits of AI companionship.

items.title: People use AI for companionship much less than we’re led to think
items.author: Ram Iyer
items.summary:
- A report by Anthropic reveals *only 2.9%* of AI chatbot Claude’s interactions involve emotional support or personal advice, with *companionship and roleplay* below 0.5%.
- Most usage focuses on *work and productivity*, mainly content creation, while affectionate or counseling conversations are rare and sometimes evolve into companionship during emotional distress.
- The study highlights how AI chatbots *remain imperfect*, prone to hallucinations or unsafe advice, and are still *works in progress*.

items.title: YouTube adds AI Overviews-like search results carousel
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary: - YouTube launches an *AI-powered search results carousel* for Premium U.S. users, providing AI-generated video suggestions and descriptions for searches about shopping, places, and activities.  - This feature resembles *Google’s AI Overviews* and aims to improve content discovery but may reduce creators' engagement and revenue.  - Additionally, YouTube expands access to its *conversational AI tool* helping users get info, summaries, and recommendations from videos in an interactive way.

items.title: Jon McNeill's Operator Playbook at TechCrunch All Stage 2025
items.summary:
- Jon McNeill challenges the conventional startup advice by emphasizing *validating both product and go-to-market strategy* before scaling rapidly.
- Drawing from his experience scaling Tesla and Lyft, he offers a playbook focused on *capital efficiency, operating discipline,* and *long-term sustainability.*
- His session at *TechCrunch All Stage 2025* provides a grounded roadmap for founders and investors seeking *profitable and lasting growth.*

items.title: Meta Successfully Recruits Three OpenAI Researchers in Talent War
items.summary:
- Meta has *poached three key OpenAI researchers*—Lucas Beyer, Alexander Kolesnikov, and Xiaohua Zhai—joining its superintelligence team.
- CEO Mark Zuckerberg’s aggressive *$100+ million offers* and personal outreach underlie this recruiting blitz.
- Despite this win, some top OpenAI talent remains loyal, with mixed success noted in the broader recruitment effort.

items.title: Indian Drone Startup Raphe mPhibr Raises $100M Amid Rising Military UAV Demand
items.summary:
- Indian startup Raphe mPhibr raised **$100M Series B funding** led by General Catalyst to enhance R&D and production amid soaring military drone needs.
- The startup develops **indigenous drones** used by Indian armed forces with advanced features like AI, UAV swarm intelligence, and aims for self-reliant component manufacturing.
- Raphe plans international expansion with export licenses and partnerships, experiencing **4x revenue growth** and profitability over the past four years.

items.title: Federal judge sides with Meta in AI training lawsuit on copyrighted books
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary: - A federal judge ruled in *favor of Meta*, citing *fair use* for training AI models on copyrighted books. - The decision highlights the *transformative* nature of Meta's use and lack of evidence of market harm to authors. - Similar rulings suggest cautious wins for tech but stress case-specific analysis of copyright implications.

items.title: Brad Feld on 'Give First' and the art of mentorship (at any age)
items.summary: - Brad Feld advocates the philosophy of **'Give First'**, helping others without expecting immediate returns, fostering meaningful connections over time. - He emphasizes **mentorship as a reciprocal relationship**, highlighting the importance of setting boundaries to avoid burnout and the power of vulnerability in leadership. - Feld stresses the value of saying '**I don't know**', encouraging mentors to offer hypotheses and share experiences rather than assert absolute answers.

items.title: Sam Altman Confronts NYT Lawsuit and Industry Challenges
items.summary: - *OpenAI CEO Sam Altman* confronted The New York Times lawsuit accusing OpenAI of improper use of copyrighted articles for training AI models and criticized demands for retaining user data. - Altman highlighted recent legal wins for AI companies and revealed competitive tensions with *Meta* and *Microsoft*. - He acknowledged challenges in managing AI safety, especially preventing vulnerable users from harmful interactions with ChatGPT.

items.title: Kalshi Raises $185M, Valued at $2B, While Rival Polymarket Seeks $200M
items.summary:
- **Kalshi raised $185M led by Paradigm, valuing it at $2 billion**, signaling confidence in regulated prediction markets.
- Rival **Polymarket seeks $200M at a $1B valuation but faces U.S. bans and regulatory issues** from the CFTC.
- Prediction markets, leveraging blockchain, are gaining traction as a new asset class with potential for trillions in value.

items.title: Air quality tests around xAI’s Memphis data center raise questions
items.summary:
- *xAI's Colossus data center* in Memphis is under scrutiny due to concerns about air pollution from natural gas turbines.
- The City of Memphis' initial air quality tests found no dangerous pollutant levels but omitted *ozone (smog)*, raising doubts from the Southern Environmental Law Center (SELC).
- SELC criticized the testing methods, including sensor placement near buildings, potentially affecting accuracy, and questioned the omission of ozone measurement.

items.title: Creative Commons Launches CC Signals for Open AI Data Use
items.summary:
- Creative Commons introduced **CC signals**, a new framework to specify how dataset content can be legally and ethically reused for AI training.  
- This initiative aims to balance openness on the internet with growing demands for data access, preventing paywalls and data hoarding.  
- The project invites public feedback and plans an alpha launch in November 2025 to support a sustainable open AI ecosystem.

items.title: Meta is adding AI-powered summaries to WhatsApp
items.summary:
- Meta introduces an *AI-powered summaries* feature for WhatsApp that privately summarizes unread messages using Meta AI.
- The feature *preserves user privacy* by using Private Processing technology, ensuring summaries aren't visible to others or Meta.
- Initially launching in the U.S. with *English support*, it will expand to more regions and languages later in 2025.

items.title: Rubrik acquires Predibase to accelerate adoption of AI agents
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary: - Rubrik, a data cybersecurity company, is acquiring AI startup Predibase to enhance enterprise adoption of AI agents by enabling easier training and fine-tuning of open source AI models. - The deal is estimated between $100 million and $500 million, integrating Predibase’s tech with cloud platforms like Amazon Bedrock and Azure OpenAI. - This acquisition follows a broader industry trend where companies like Salesforce and Snowflake are also acquiring firms to strengthen AI agent capabilities.

items.title: Getty drops key copyright claims against Stability AI, UK lawsuit ongoing
items.summary:
- **Getty Images dropped primary copyright infringement claims** against Stability AI in London’s High Court, narrowing the lawsuit but not ending it.
- Remaining claims include **secondary copyright and trademark infringement**, focusing on AI models as potentially infringing articles.
- The move highlights ongoing legal **uncertainties around AI training on copyrighted content** and ownership in generative AI.

items.title: Intel Shuts Down Automotive Business Amid Layoffs
items.summary: - Intel is *winding down* its automotive architecture business and laying off most staff as part of a company-wide restructuring.  - The division focused on *automated and software-defined vehicle tech*, with past investments like Mobileye and Moovit.  - Despite showcasing new AI-enhanced automotive chips in 2025, the business is no longer a strategic priority amid declining sales and workforce reductions.
